text: Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Doctor: But, yeah, like when you fly- Patient: I was trying to- Doctor: Like when you fly to Europe, you kind of fly up over, like if you’re going to England, you fly up over Greenland and down. Patient: Yeah. That’s what they did. That’s exactly what they did. Doctor: It’s shorter somehow. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right.

text: Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: I didn’t ever know. I didn’t realize, I didn’t realize this is my third year doing it, and I didn’t realize I was - Doctor: No shave, but I, I think that’s what that fundraiser is for. Doctor: They give, uh, grants and do a lot of support for, uh- Yeah, this is my eighth year. (softly) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: I’m going through your medicines. Still taking your Advair as needed? Patient: Right. Doctor: Your atorvastatin ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes.

text: Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month?

Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month?

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We sort of made that be like uh a line in the sand so to speak, so- Patient: What about the PSMA, uh? Doctor: So that was going to be the next thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
